title: No Junk folder on new, single-account Thunderbird installation
content:
I've been using Thunderbird now for over a month and am delighted with its performance. So much so that I chose Thunderbird as the mail handler on a new laptop for my wife.

I have three mail (POP) accounts on my own desktop computer and utilize the Unified Folders mode for most everything. My wife has only a single gmail (POP) account, the only one active on the new laptop. The trouble is, there is no Junk mail folder for that account on her laptop. I probably saw this initially and figured that the folder would appear as soon as something went into it. But with some mail accumulated over the past few days, nothing has gone in AND... messages in the Inbox that are manually marked as Junk go from boldface to normal font (as if they were read), but do not disappear into the nonexistent Junk folder. I have Junk folders on all three of my desktop computer accounts, all of which function as expected. What might be going on here?

title: View of Email too Short for Laptop Window
content:
There are times when individual emails have embedded pictures which do not fully show on my short-but-wide laptop screen. Is there a way to change the density of the headers in individual emails? Compact Density view gets the overall inbox back to how I want it, without wasting space and showing fewer email on the visible screen. However, inside an individual email there seems to be a lot of wasted space between each line of the header (From, To, Reply To, and Subject). If we had a "compact" view for the headers, it would allow us to see a little more of each email on the screen.

Or maybe the real problem is the new tabbed email? I can't remember exactly what my emails looked like before the upgrade, but I just know they look different now and the tab bars and menu bars above the individual email look odd. Whether or not the new version affected the visible vertical area of individual emails, I think we need a way to view a single email in "full screen," without all the menu bars. Currently, if we right-click on the tab for an individual email and select "move to new window," the entire program with tabs opens in a new window (Inbox tab, Tab with the email). It doesn't change the single tab into a new window the way "move to new window" on an internet browser tab does.

So can you please look at doing something to allow us be able to see more of an email on the screen without having to zoom out and making the text too hard to read?

I am attaching a screenshot which shows the header with the wasted space and also the picture which cannot be viewed in full on my short-but-wide laptop screen. Compacting the header would help some but not a lot. Opening the email in it's own window without the tab bar would help more, and being able to make that window full-screen (without the menu bars showing in green on my picture) would help a LOT.

Thank you.
creator: ajp1228

title: Set IMAP so that local copy does NOT get deleted when it's deleted from the server (1-way sync)
content:
IMAP can be viewed in two ways. One is as a flexible protocol for moving mail between clients and servers. The other is as a rigid way to create a sort of view-port into a server, where it only shows messages that are on the server and treats the local copies as a temporary cache. The former approach is by far more appropriate for a public ISP server, while the latter is more suited to a corporate office where IT controls the mail and has legal obligations to manage it on a server.

It appears to me that Thunderbird's IMAP is only the corporate kind -- it synchronizes with the server but does not keep mail that the server deletes. Hence in order to use it with persistent mail, you need a server that keeps all of your mail on it reliably and feeds it up.

Enter Yahoo!, once upon a time a major SAAS player. Yahoo! has a webmail product. It also has POP and IMAP, sort of. But they're completely and totally enschyttified the IMAP. There are two HUGE things that make it no longer work with T'bird. One is that they've limited the IMAP to 10,000 messages. Older messages are still there on their web mail, but they are no longer accessible on IMAP. So unless you've used POP to download them into a separate mailbox, bye bye mail. This would not be a problem if T'bird allowed one-way sync, wherein it downloaded the messages from the IMAP server and KEPT THEM no matter what the server did. But I don't see how to do that.The only hack I know of is to filter them and have the filter copy to another folder. But in practice that is NOT reliable. Many messages did not get filtered, perhaps because the other folder is already saving messages in POP, the only workaround that works.

The second enschyttification of Yahoo! is that its spam filtering is now utterly persistent. That is, you can go in on the web site or in IMAP and mark it not spam and move it to the INBOX, but within five minutes it WILL be put back in the spam folder. They think it's spam and nothing you tell them will change their mind! This happens so fast that POP may not even catch the message before its next cycle. So again, being able to move it to the IMAP inbox and have it STAY there is vital to making IMAP useful again.

Please don't tell me this violates the IMAP protocol spec. It doesn't - the protocol is a flexible tool.

Any chance this is possible in T'bird 102 or, less likely, 115? Or might it be a viable suggestion for some future version once it's stable or rebuilt again?
creator: fred37

title: My problems with the new (and old) Thunderbird
content:
I am afraid that I am not at all happy with the new version of Thunderbird. It may be that as I get used to it I will find some of the new features helpful, but right now I am more concerned about what was taken away that was helpful: 

   a) I keep getting 'not responding' -- especially when trying to set my theme 'yet again (and again, and again)!!!!  I am mostly shut-in due to illness and the themes make a difference emotionally compared to a stark 'black and white'.  Furthermore, what is the point of having TB themes when they don't hold -- I often have to re-set mine several times a day 
   b) tabs are now hidden -- I need to colour-code messages so I know which I need to get back to soon or can wait. Having them hidden under that new right arrow makes extra steps to do so 
   c) the row of custom colours no longer hold: what is the point of being able set a row of custom colour if they don't hold!!!  I used different colours to indicate different responses in a thread -- thereby having an immediate way to see the order of responses. 
   d) I need layers of sub-folders -- often to add a new name to a group I belong to, or a new year.  I have been asking again and again over several years for the ability to create a new sub-folder WHILE one is moving an email from the inbox to a folder or sub-folder.  Having to 'go' to the folder first, make a new sub-subfolder, return to the inbox, and then move the email is an unnecessary waste of time.  
   e) 'a picture says a thousand words' -- emojs are so useful in this way, especially when one is tired or can't think of the right words to say.  This feature was taken away years ago, and I wish that TB would bring it back.  The minimal 'yellow faces' are minimal useful. 
   I am not techy enough to really understand what you have written below - what is a 'message context menu' and 'mock-ups'.  However, it seems to me that the TB functons (at least the ones that I need) are getting less and less useful and increasing 'cognitive burden'. 
   Sorry to be so negative, but I do wonder who TB is trying to please/appease -- it is not this user. 
   Blessings
creator: quaternalmoon131

title: After update to v115 Calendar is displayed only until Saturday, Sunday and buttons are cut off
content:
Dear Thunderbird community,

After the big update to version 115 of Thunderbird (the new Supernova thing), my calendar doesn't display correctly anymore.

As you can see in the attached screenshot, the calendar displays the week from Monday (in the screenshot "Montag" in German) to Friday, and then 2/3 of Saturday ("Samstag" in German). So Sunday is completely missing, and along with it the buttons to change to daily/weekly/multiple weeks/monthly view, and the one for "calendar layout options," aren't accessable anymore.

The problem occurs only on my laptop screen, not on my bigger external one. Here are some key facts about my screens:

  • laptop screen (the smaller one): resolution 1920 x 1080, Windows zoom 150% (recommended), 14 inches diagonally, set as main screen, so on this one is the taskbar (remaining resolution for the Thunderbird window: 1920 x 1020)
  • external screen (the larger one): resolution 1920 x 1200, Windows zoom 100% (recommended), 24 inches diagonally, no taskbar

If I reduce the Windows Zoom on the laptop screen to 100%, the problem doesn't occur. However, this is not an acceptable solution because I can't read my screen anymore.

I've already tried in vain the options of the hamburger menu and the settings, several restarts of the app and my computer. I have also searched the forum and the internet for similar problems with this update, but haven't found anything fitting. And I checked for new updates (in hope the next update will already fix the problem), so I updated Thunderbird once since the big update to 115/Supernova and now have version 115.3.1. (But that didn't help either.)

Key facts about my system: Windows 10 Professional, 21H2 | Laptop Dell Latitude 5400 (bought in 11/2020) | Thunderbird 115.3.1 (64-Bit)

I would be glad if someone could give me advice on how to fix this problem.

Sincerely

title: Donate and Privacy
content: Today the "new" version of Thunderbird started. T don't know yet if that is better than the older versions, but that's not the question. I was asked to donate to Thunderbird when I opened the new version and I wanted to do that, as I have supported Thunderbird earlier. But: after having given my name and email address so you can contact me that you received the payment, I was obliged to give you my home address, ZIP-code, place where I live etc. and I could not leave that open before I could contribute to Thunderbird. There is no reason that you need my home address before I can donate to your organization, so I stopped there and did NOT donate. I think that is is a stupid policy to ask for more private data than necessary. Maybe nice for your promotional department, but you lost me as a supporter.
creator: tonson1981

title: Thunderbird hangs on Copying to Sent folder
content: Since the new version of Thunderbird after nearly every email I make I got a popup that the message I sent cannot be placed in the Sent folder. After several minutes it still hangs and if I then close the popup screen I'm told that the message was sent, but that the copy was placed in Sent of my local folder and not in Sent of my IMAP account. I had that earlier with earlier versions of Thunderbird but then only a few times in a months. With this "new" version it happens every time. It seems that something is broken in this "new"version.
creator: tonson1981

title: Thunderbird
content:
Have a nice day, congratulations on the Thunderbird update, which seems to offer many practical innovations. But I see a major flaw in the fact that you now have to press the Tab key twice from the Inbox folder, for example, to get to the incoming mail. The line "Subject, Involved..." I usually need only once. So I ask to remove this tab stop again. It is a completely unnecessary additional step.

Thank you and best regards Michael Moessmer
creator: redaktion4

title: disappearing messages from the server and inbox
content:
Good morning ,

For some time now, e-mail messages have been disappearing from my inbox. (I found out when I tried to find the message in the history) I checked with the supplier home.pl and according to their technicians there is no problem on their side. According to home.pl, the problem lies with Thunderbird and probably with the program's internal settings. It is possible that emails are archived to a file every 30 days (home.pl opinion) However, I don't remember setting up Thunderbird this way. Please help me how to recover or possibly find a file containing e-mails that disappeared only from my inbox. Messages in the sent folder are retained.
creator: lukasz26

content: Since Thunderbird updated at the end of September 2023 the list of emails is in type too small for me to read comfortably. Thunderbird is supposed to be customizeable - but I cannot find a way of fixing this. It seems that only the type of the emails themselves can be altered. I use Windows 10 on a Lenovo Yoga, browser Firefox. I cannot take a screenshot of Thunderbird I'm afraid. Thank you!

title: Importing profiles does not bring in e-mail messages
content:
Linux Mint went bad on me and destroyed my TB program files, though I have access to the .thunderbird folder. However, the Import function will not restore e-mail messages or Calendar Settings, no matter what version or method I've tried, though it has gotten Address Book and Account Settings intact.

The original Profile system is from way back - fifteen years at least, and has been migrating ever since, up until now. I can see the individual Inbox files and so on, some of them quite large, and examined through Libre Writer so I know they're intact at least. I just can't get them to show in TB, even with manually installing them in the .thunderbird folder.

I do not know what version I was using before Linux failed, but it was not too old - I was performing regular updates - but was also not 115. I have presently installed 109 Beta, but can change to whatever version will work.

Is there a way to get the Import to recognize this old profile (it has a .IETimport suffix) or alternately, manually transfer it so it can be found?

Let me know whatever other information is needed. Thanks!
creator: wadingbarefoot

title: Authentication failure while connecting to imap.gmail.com after auto upgrade to version 115.3.1 (64-bit)
content:
My TB has been running for years with 2 gmails, 1 outlook and 2 aliyun.com emails mbox.

Days ago the TB upgrade to 115 via auto responding to update check.

however, after upgrade, i cannot connect to gmails ( while outlook and aliyun still ok )

it keeps complaining 'authentication failed'

i check the setting is SSL with Oauth2 that should be correct.

i tried add a new gmail account ( 3rd gmail other than the existing 2 ), i click auto configure in the email setup wizard, it also stuck at checking password. i double check the password is correct.

do you have any idea? how i should approach to fix this issue.

title: Migrating ubuntu computers as well as upgrading from TB 38.8.0 to TB 115
content:
I'm moving from an old computer running ubuntu 14.08 & TH 31.8.0 to newer computer running ubuntu 22.04.3 LTS & TB 115.

I manually created my email accounts in 115 and that went flawlessly - all my folders & messages came right in. My email accounrs are IMAP.

The MAJOR issue is I have vital business records i have created for years in Tasks in Lightening Calendar in my TB 31.8.0 install and MUST be able to import them into the new 115.

In reading threads here, it appears i first have to bring my profile from TB 38.8.0 into TB 78.14.0, then take that profile & bring it into TB 115. Do i have this right?

If so, do i just copy the 31.8.0 profile into the .Thunderbird directory of 78.14.0 & open TB. Then take that profile & bring it into TB 115?

Will my filters come along with this action automatically?

Thanks in advance!
creator: thedudeabides2011

title: Thunderbird Supernova userChrome Not Working

title: Latest Thunderbird Update Not Loading (win10)
content:

I then tried to open Thunderbird and a message comes up to the effect that I am trying to open an old version of Thunderbird and the profiles have been altered by a later version etc.

I have searched the machine and the only Thunderbird.exe is dated 2020.

I can't attach the log file as its not an image. I could copy and paste the contents but it is a large file.
